thread.title: Lion refuses to move until his ranger strokes his mane
thread.title_full: Lion refuses to move until his ranger strokes his mane

title: Lion refuses to move until his ranger strokes his mane
text: Share this article Share 'It also gives us some security too. Every morning when Mike comes in to work he has this ritual with Smokey to get him back into his own camp so we can use the passage for vehicles. 'It is our belief that Smokey often delays this process for more attention from Mike, who is his favourite person. 'But after all, Smokey is a big cat, and we all know that everything with cats is on their own terms.' The lion is seen walking down the road towards Mike, before stopping in the middle of the road After eventually agreeing to move, he stops again at the gate. Mike gently tries to coax him back into the park Glen Garriff is home to 80 lions and aims to promote the study, learning and understanding of the species. The organisation aims to preserve their African lion gene pool, with lions selectively bred from eight family groups to keep the animals disease-free. Ms Scott said: 'We love our work as it enables us to live closely with the most superior iconic predator in the world. 'We monitor and watch their behaviour and we listen to their roars all night long with is bone chillingly amazing.' Smokey refuses to budge until Mike starts cuddling him and stroking his mane Read more: Share or comment on this article Most watched News videos
